column1: Ebola is a severe and often deadly disease caused by a virus.
Ebola can occur in humans and other primates (gorillas, monkeys, and chimpanzees).

The countries most affected in this outbreak include: - Guinea - Liberia - Sierra Leone Ebola was previously reported in: - Nigeria - Senegal - Spain - United States - Mali - United Kingdom - Italy There are no current cases of Ebola in these countries.

Ebola can also spread by contact with ANY surfaces, objects, and materials that have been in contact with body fluids from a sick person, such as: - Bedclothes and bedding - Clothing - Bandages - Needles and syringes - Medical equipment In Africa, Ebola may also be spread by: - Handling infected wild animals hunted for food (bushmeat) - Contact with blood or body fluids of infected animals - Contact with infected bats Ebola does NOT spread through: - Air - Water - Food - Insects (mosquitoes) Health care workers and people caring for sick relatives are most at risk for developing Ebola because they are more likely to come in to direct contact with body fluids.
